tools.name: read_documentation
tools.description:
Fetch and convert an AWS documentation page to markdown format.

## Usage

This tool retrieves the content of an AWS documentation page and converts it to markdown format.
For long documents, you can make multiple calls with different start_index values to retrieve
the entire content in chunks.

## URL Requirements

- Must be from the docs.aws.amazon.com domain
- Must end with .html

## Example URLs

- https://docs.aws.amazon.com/AmazonS3/latest/userguide/bucketnamingrules.html
- https://docs.aws.amazon.com/lambda/latest/dg/lambda-invocation.html

## Output Format

The output is formatted as markdown text with:
- Preserved headings and structure
- Code blocks for examples
- Lists and tables converted to markdown format

## Handling Long Documents

If the response indicates the document was truncated, you have several options:

1. **Continue Reading**: Make another call with start_index set to the end of the previous response
2. **Stop Early**: For very long documents (>30,000 characters), if you've already found the specific information needed, you can stop reading

Args:
    ctx: MCP context for logging and error handling
    url: URL of the AWS documentation page to read
    max_length: Maximum number of characters to return
    start_index: On return output starting at this character index

Returns:
    Markdown content of the AWS documentation

url.description: URL of the AWS documentation page to read
url.title: Url

max_length.description: Maximum number of characters to return.
max_length.title: Max Length

start_index.description: On return output starting at this character index, useful if a previous fetch was truncated and more content is required.
start_index.title: Start Index

tools.name: search_documentation
tools.description:
Search AWS documentation using the official AWS Documentation Search API.

## Usage

This tool searches across all AWS documentation for pages matching your search phrase.
Use it to find relevant documentation when you don't have a specific URL.

## Search Tips

- Use specific technical terms rather than general phrases
- Include service names to narrow results (e.g., "S3 bucket versioning" instead of just "versioning")
- Use quotes for exact phrase matching (e.g., "AWS Lambda function URLs")
- Include abbreviations and alternative terms to improve results

## Result Interpretation

Each result includes:
- rank_order: The relevance ranking (lower is more relevant)
- url: The documentation page URL
- title: The page title
- context: A brief excerpt or summary (if available)

Args:
    ctx: MCP context for logging and error handling
    search_phrase: Search phrase to use
    limit: Maximum number of results to return

Returns:
    List of search results with URLs, titles, query ID, and context snippets

limit.description: Maximum number of results to return
limit.title: Limit

tools.name: recommend
tools.description:
Get content recommendations for an AWS documentation page.

## Usage

This tool provides recommendations for related AWS documentation pages based on a given URL.
Use it to discover additional relevant content that might not appear in search results.

## Recommendation Types

The recommendations include four categories:

1. **Highly Rated**: Popular pages within the same AWS service
2. **New**: Recently added pages within the same AWS service - useful for finding newly released features
3. **Similar**: Pages covering similar topics to the current page
4. **Journey**: Pages commonly viewed next by other users

## When to Use

- After reading a documentation page to find related content
- When exploring a new AWS service to discover important pages
- To find alternative explanations of complex concepts
- To discover the most popular pages for a service
- To find newly released information by using a service's welcome page URL and checking the **New** recommendations

## Finding New Features

To find newly released information about a service:
1. Find any page belong to that service, typically you can try the welcome page
2. Call this tool with that URL
3. Look specifically at the **New** recommendation type in the results

## Result Interpretation

Each recommendation includes:
- url: The documentation page URL
- title: The page title
- context: A brief description (if available)

Args:
    ctx: MCP context for logging and error handling
    url: URL of the AWS documentation page to get recommendations for

Returns:
    List of recommended pages with URLs, titles, and context

url.description: URL of the AWS documentation page to get recommendations for
url.title: Url

content.text: I'll search for information about S3 object size limits.

{
  "rank_order": 1,
  "url": "https://docs.aws.amazon.com/AmazonS3/latest/userguide/qfacts.html",
  "title": "Amazon S3 multipart upload limits - Amazon Simple Storage Service",
  "query_id": "f2bdb6a1-841a-4c3a-aaa3-40b12e6e0a1d",
  "context": "Multipart upload enables uploading large objects by splitting into parts, assembling parts into single object, with limits on object size, part size, part count."
}

{
  "rank_order": 2,
  "url": "https://docs.aws.amazon.com/AmazonS3/latest/API/API_control_MatchObjectSize.html",
  "title": "MatchObjectSize - Amazon Simple Storage Service",
  "query_id": "f2bdb6a1-841a-4c3a-aaa3-40b12e6e0a1d",
  "context": "A filter condition that specifies the object size range of included objects in bytes. Only integers are supported."
}

{
  "rank_order": 3,
  "url": "https://docs.aws.amazon.com/guardduty/latest/ug/malware-protection-s3-quotas-guardduty.html",
  "title": "Quotas in Malware Protection for S3 - Amazon GuardDuty",
  "query_id": "f2bdb6a1-841a-4c3a-aaa3-40b12e6e0a1d",
  "context": "Malware scanning limits: 100GB object size, 100GB extracted archive bytes, 1,000 extracted archive files, 5 archive depth levels, 25 protected S3 buckets per Region."
}

{
  "rank_order": 4,
  "url": "https://docs.aws.amazon.com/sdk-for-kotlin/api/latest/macie2/aws.sdk.kotlin.services.macie2.model/-s3-object/size.html",
  "title": "size - AWS SDK for Kotlin",
  "query_id": "f2bdb6a1-841a-4c3a-aaa3-40b12e6e0a1d",
  "context": "Learn how to use size in the AWS SDK for Kotlin"
}

{
  "rank_order": 5,
  "url": "https://docs.aws.amazon.com/amazondynamodb/latest/developerguide/S3DataImport.BestPractices.html",
  "title": "Best practices for importing from Amazon S3 into DynamoDB - Amazon DynamoDB",
  "query_id": "f2bdb6a1-841a-4c3a-aaa3-40b12e6e0a1d",
  "context": "Randomize sorted data, compress below Regional limit, consider item size impact, import without Global Secondary Indexes"
}

{
  "rank_order": 6,
  "url": "https://docs.aws.amazon.com/sdk-for-kotlin/api/latest/s3/aws.sdk.kotlin.services.s3.model/-object-identifier/size.html",
  "title": "size - AWS SDK for Kotlin",
  "query_id": "f2bdb6a1-841a-4c3a-aaa3-40b12e6e0a1d",
  "context": "Learn how to use size in the AWS SDK for Kotlin"
}

{
  "rank_order": 7,
  "url": "https://docs.aws.amazon.com/athena/latest/ug/notebooks-spark-troubleshooting-code-block-size-limit.html",
  "title": "Overcome the 68k code block size limit - Amazon Athena",
  "query_id": "f2bdb6a1-841a-4c3a-aaa3-40b12e6e0a1d",
  "context": "Overcome 68k code block size limit by uploading file to Amazon S3 and reading it with boto3 to run large SQL queries or Python code blocks."
}

{
  "rank_order": 8,
  "url": "https://docs.aws.amazon.com/sdk-for-kotlin/api/latest/s3/aws.sdk.kotlin.services.s3.model/-object-version/size.html",
  "title": "size - AWS SDK for Kotlin",
  "query_id": "f2bdb6a1-841a-4c3a-aaa3-40b12e6e0a1d",
  "context": "Learn how to use size in the AWS SDK for Kotlin"
}

{
  "rank_order": 9,
  "url": "https://docs.aws.amazon.com/amazondynamodb/latest/developerguide/bp-use-s3-too.html",
  "title": "Best practices for storing large items and attributes in DynamoDB - Amazon DynamoDB",
  "query_id": "f2bdb6a1-841a-4c3a-aaa3-40b12e6e0a1d",
  "context": "Store large attribute values in Amazon S3, break large items into smaller chunks, compress large attribute values, monitor item sizes with ReturnConsumedCapacity, vertical partitioning to scale data, use Amazon S3 object metadata, organize data to avoid long object identifiers."
}

{
  "rank_order": 10,
  "url": "https://docs.aws.amazon.com/sdk-for-kotlin/api/latest/s3/aws.sdk.kotlin.services.s3.model/-object/size.html",
  "title": "size - AWS SDK for Kotlin",
  "query_id": "f2bdb6a1-841a-4c3a-aaa3-40b12e6e0a1d",
  "context": "Learn how to use size in the AWS SDK for Kotlin"
}

content.text: Let me read the first result about S3 multipart upload limits, which seems most relevant:

AWS Documentation from https://docs.aws.amazon.com/AmazonS3/latest/userguide/qfacts.html:

# Amazon S3 multipart upload limits

Multipart upload allows you to upload a single object as a set of parts. Each part is a
contiguous portion of the object's data. After all parts of your object are uploaded, Amazon S3
assembles these parts and creates the object. In general, when your object size reaches 100
MB, you should consider using multipart uploads instead of uploading the object in a single
operation. For more information about multipart uploads, see [Uploading and copying objects using multipart upload in Amazon S3](./mpuoverview.html "./mpuoverview.html").

The following table provides multipart upload core specifications. These include maximum
object size, maximum number of parts, maximum part size, and more. There is no minimum size
limit on the last part of your multipart upload.

| Item | Specification |
| --- | --- |
| Maximum object size | 5 TiB |
| Maximum number of parts per upload | 10,000 |
| Part numbers | 1 to 10,000 (inclusive) |
| Part size | 5 MiB to 5 GiB. There is no minimum size limit on the last part of your multipart upload. |
| Maximum number of parts returned for a list parts request | 1000 |
| Maximum number of multipart uploads returned in a list multipart uploads request | 1000 |

messages.content: what is the max size of an object we can put in s3

AWS Documentation from https://docs.aws.amazon.com/AmazonS3/latest/userguide/qfacts.html:

# Amazon S3 multipart upload limits

Multipart upload allows you to upload a single object as a set of parts. Each part is a
contiguous portion of the object's data. After all parts of your object are uploaded, Amazon S3
assembles these parts and creates the object. In general, when your object size reaches 100
MB, you should consider using multipart uploads instead of uploading the object in a single
operation. For more information about multipart uploads, see [Uploading and copying objects using multipart upload in Amazon S3](./mpuoverview.html "./mpuoverview.html").

The following table provides multipart upload core specifications. These include maximum
object size, maximum number of parts, maximum part size, and more. There is no minimum size
limit on the last part of your multipart upload.

| Item | Specification |
| --- | --- |
| Maximum object size | 5 TiB |
| Maximum number of parts per upload | 10,000 |
| Part numbers | 1 to 10,000 (inclusive) |
| Part size | 5 MiB to 5 GiB. There is no minimum size limit on the last part of your multipart upload. |
| Maximum number of parts returned for a list parts request | 1000 |
| Maximum number of multipart uploads returned in a list multipart uploads request | 1000 |

tools.name: read_documentation
tools.description:
Fetch and convert an AWS documentation page to markdown format.

## Usage

This tool retrieves the content of an AWS documentation page and converts it to markdown format.
For long documents, you can make multiple calls with different start_index values to retrieve
the entire content in chunks.

## URL Requirements

- Must be from the docs.aws.amazon.com domain
- Must end with .html

## Example URLs

- https://docs.aws.amazon.com/AmazonS3/latest/userguide/bucketnamingrules.html
- https://docs.aws.amazon.com/lambda/latest/dg/lambda-invocation.html

## Output Format

The output is formatted as markdown text with:
- Preserved headings and structure
- Code blocks for examples
- Lists and tables converted to markdown format

## Handling Long Documents

If the response indicates the document was truncated, you have several options:

1. **Continue Reading**: Make another call with start_index set to the end of the previous response
2. **Stop Early**: For very long documents (>30,000 characters), if you've already found the specific information needed, you can stop reading

Args:
    ctx: MCP context for logging and error handling
    url: URL of the AWS documentation page to read
    max_length: Maximum number of characters to return
    start_index: On return output starting at this character index

Returns:
    Markdown content of the AWS documentation

tools.name: search_documentation
tools.description:
Search AWS documentation using the official AWS Documentation Search API.

## Usage

This tool searches across all AWS documentation for pages matching your search phrase.
Use it to find relevant documentation when you don't have a specific URL.

## Search Tips

- Use specific technical terms rather than general phrases
- Include service names to narrow results (e.g., "S3 bucket versioning" instead of just "versioning")
- Use quotes for exact phrase matching (e.g., "AWS Lambda function URLs")
- Include abbreviations and alternative terms to improve results

## Result Interpretation

Each result includes:
- rank_order: The relevance ranking (lower is more relevant)
- url: The documentation page URL
- title: The page title
- context: A brief excerpt or summary (if available)

Args:
    ctx: MCP context for logging and error handling
    search_phrase: Search phrase to use
    limit: Maximum number of results to return

Returns:
    List of search results with URLs, titles, query ID, and context snippets

tools.name: recommend
tools.description:
Get content recommendations for an AWS documentation page.

## Usage

This tool provides recommendations for related AWS documentation pages based on a given URL.
Use it to discover additional relevant content that might not appear in search results.

## Recommendation Types

The recommendations include four categories:

1. **Highly Rated**: Popular pages within the same AWS service
2. **New**: Recently added pages within the same AWS service - useful for finding newly released features
3. **Similar**: Pages covering similar topics to the current page
4. **Journey**: Pages commonly viewed next by other users

## When to Use

- After reading a documentation page to find related content
- When exploring a new AWS service to discover important pages
- To find alternative explanations of complex concepts
- To discover the most popular pages for a service
- To find newly released information by using a service's welcome page URL and checking the **New** recommendations

## Finding New Features

To find newly released information about a service:
1. Find any page belong to that service, typically you can try the welcome page
2. Call this tool with that URL
3. Look specifically at the **New** recommendation type in the results

## Result Interpretation

Each recommendation includes:
- url: The documentation page URL
- title: The page title
- context: A brief description (if available)

Args:
    ctx: MCP context for logging and error handling
    url: URL of the AWS documentation page to get recommendations for

Returns:
    List of recommended pages with URLs, titles, and context

content.text:
AWS Documentation from https://docs.aws.amazon.com/AmazonS3/latest/userguide/qfacts.html:

# Amazon S3 multipart upload limits

Multipart upload allows you to upload a single object as a set of parts. Each part is a
contiguous portion of the object's data. After all parts of your object are uploaded, Amazon S3
assembles these parts and creates the object. In general, when your object size reaches 100
MB, you should consider using multipart uploads instead of uploading the object in a single
operation. For more information about multipart uploads, see [Uploading and copying objects using multipart upload in Amazon S3](./mpuoverview.html "./mpuoverview.html").

The following table provides multipart upload core specifications. These include maximum
object size, maximum number of parts, maximum part size, and more. There is no minimum size
limit on the last part of your multipart upload.

| Item | Specification |
| --- | --- |
| Maximum object size | 5 TiB |
| Maximum number of parts per upload | 10,000 |
| Part numbers | 1 to 10,000 (inclusive) |
| Part size | 5 MiB to 5 GiB. There is no minimum size limit on the last part of your multipart upload. |
| Maximum number of parts returned for a list parts request | 1000 |
| Maximum number of multipart uploads returned in a list multipart uploads request | 1000 |

messages.content: what is the max size of an object we can put in s3

content.content:
AWS Documentation from https://docs.aws.amazon.com/AmazonS3/latest/userguide/qfacts.html:

# Amazon S3 multipart upload limits

Multipart upload allows you to upload a single object as a set of parts. Each part is a
contiguous portion of the object's data. After all parts of your object are uploaded, Amazon S3
assembles these parts and creates the object. In general, when your object size reaches 100
MB, you should consider using multipart uploads instead of uploading the object in a single
operation. For more information about multipart uploads, see [Uploading and copying objects using multipart upload in Amazon S3](./mpuoverview.html "./mpuoverview.html").

The following table provides multipart upload core specifications. These include maximum
object size, maximum number of parts, maximum part size, and more. There is no minimum size
limit on the last part of your multipart upload.

| Item | Specification |
| --- | --- |
| Maximum object size | 5 TiB |
| Maximum number of parts per upload | 10,000 |
| Part numbers | 1 to 10,000 (inclusive) |
| Part size | 5 MiB to 5 GiB. There is no minimum size limit on the last part of your multipart upload. |
| Maximum number of parts returned for a list parts request | 1000 |
| Maximum number of multipart uploads returned in a list multipart uploads request | 1000 |

content.text:
Based on the AWS documentation, the **maximum size of an object you can put in Amazon S3 is 5 TiB (tebibytes)** when using multipart upload.

Here are the key details about S3 object size limits:

- **Maximum object size**: 5 TiB (approximately 5.5 TB)
- **Recommended approach**: For objects 100 MB or larger, Amazon recommends using multipart upload instead of single-part upload
- **Multipart upload specifications**:
  - Maximum number of parts per upload: 10,000
  - Part size range: 5 MiB to 5 GiB (except the last part, which has no minimum size limit)
  - Part numbers: 1 to 10,000 (inclusive)

For smaller objects (under 100 MB), you can use regular single-part uploads, but the overall maximum object size limit of 5 TiB still applies regardless of the upload method used.
